title-group.article-title: Resting Parietal Electroencephalogram Asymmetries and Self-Reported Attentional Control

contrib-group.aff: 1University of the Balearic Islands, University Research Institute on Health Sciences (IUNICS), Palma, Spain

author-notes.corresp: Alfonso Morillas-Romero, University of the Balearic Islands, University Research Institute on Health Sciences (IUNICS), Carretera de Valldemossa km.7.5. 07122 Palma, Spain Email: alfonsomorillas83@gmail.com

abstract.p: Research on electroencephalogram (EEG) asymmetries and anxiety proneness has recently spread to emotion regulation capabilities. We studied whether attentional control (AC), a temperamental construct related to emotional regulation, was associated with asymmetrical patterns of resting EEG activity at the frontal and parietal regions, reflected not only in the α frequency band (8-13 Hz) but also in higher bands β1 (13-20 Hz) and β2 (20-30 Hz). Self-reports of AC and trait anxiety, and resting EEG recordings, were obtained from 58 healthy participants. Correlational analysis showed that lower levels of self-reported AC were associated with less α, β1, and β2 powers in the left parietal cortex, while no significant relationships were found between the AC and EEG oscillations in the prefrontal cortex. The role of the left and right parietal lobes in the attentional processes is discussed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
AC refers to the cognitive ability to regulate attentional allocation, and is considered a key component for effective emotion regulation. Low AC and/or difficulties in disengaging attention have been linked to increased self-focused emotion regulation strategies such as perseverative thinking. 1,2 AC has also been reported to moderate the relationship between negative affectivity and anxious and depressive symptomatology. 3 Recent studies using nonemotionally laden tasks 4
–7 have pointed out that attentional biases in anxiety could reflect a much broader dysregulation of AC, influencing general attentional processing. Therefore, if AC is a trait-like disposition, it seems reasonable that individual differences in self-reported AC could be reflected in specific patterns of resting EEG activity.

Although previous research has focused on prefrontal EEG α activity as a possible correlate of emotion regulation capabilities, the literature on the relationships between attentional processes and parietal activity has stressed the important role of these brain areas. 8
–11 Self-reported measures of distractibility accurately predicted gray matter volume in a focal region of the left superior parietal cortex. 12 Right posterior parietal cortex has been proposed 12,13 to be engaged when salient information must be selected, and the left posterior parietal cortex is engaged when salient information must be ignored. In the same direction, Li et al 14 reported that AC may be associated with right lateralized activity at the temporoparietal and ventrofrontal cortex. Also, increased parietal right-lateralized β activity (13-30 Hz) at the baseline seems to be associated with greater flight responses to angry facial expressions. 15

All EEG studies, except the last one 15 focused on α rhythm (8-13 Hz) and its standard interpretation as a sign of idling (ie, the brain remains in standby). However, Knyazev 16 proposed that α oscillations play an important inhibitory role in a variety of cognitive processes, because inhibitory mechanisms in different behavioral and biological phenomena are more necessary in active than idling states. Regarding attentional processes, increased α oscillations could reflect an anticipatory state, where attention to irrelevant stimuli is inhibited. In that sense, the study of β band (13-30 Hz) oscillations could provide helpful information to interpret any findings in α band oscillations. For example, if low AC is associated with decreased cortical activity in the left parietal cortex region P3, we should find lowered β power at P3, and, if Knyazev’s interpretation is correct, α band power might also be lowered at P3. Furthermore, we explored the potential existence of asymmetries in complexity by studying the fractal dimension (FD) of the EEG recordings 17 , in order to supplement information obtained in previous traditional analysis.

The current study analyzed whether AC is associated with resting α and β EEG activity in the frontal and parietal areas. We hypothesized that low AC will correspond to low left frontoparietal EEG activity (ie, right-sided predominance of α and β oscillations). If this pattern of EEG activity is directly related to AC, then these associations should remain significant after controlling for trait anxiety. As to the asymmetries in complexity, as far as high FD values reflect more intense mental activity, we hypothesized that the pattern of asymmetry is close to the pattern for β oscillations, that is higher right-sided complexity corresponds to low AC ability.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: EEG recordings from 58 right-handed adults (22 women, 36 men; mean [M] age = 25.18 years, standard deviation [SD] = 7.37), who had been assessed through questionnaires on attentional control and trait anxiety, were analyzed. All participants were asked about neurological and psychiatric disorders, and to refrain from alcohol, drug use, and caffeinated beverages for 4 hours prior to participation.

sec.title: Attentional control
sec.p: The AC subscale of the Adult Temperament Questionnaire 18 was used. The subscale comprises 5 items to be rated subjectively on a 7-point Likert-type scale (1 = extremely untrue, and 7 = extremely true). For our sample, the AC subscale total internal consistency was α = .773.

sec.title: Trait anxiety
sec.p: The State-Trait Anxiety Inventory, Trait Version 19 was used. It consists of 20 statements measuring subjective feelings of anxiety in a 4-point scale (0 = almost never; 3 = almost always). For our sample, the scale’s total internal consistency was α = .920.

sec.title: Recording, Processing, and Analysis of the EEG Signals
sec.p: After a 3-minute adaptation period, we recorded the EEG activity during an 8-minute resting baseline (BL): 2 minutes eyes open (EO1), 2 minutes eyes closed (EC1), 2 minutes EO (EO2), and 2 minutes EC (EC2). Neurophysiological recordings were conducted in a dimly lit and sound-attenuated room. The EEG signals were recorded using a Lycra stretch cap (CAP100C, BIOPAC Systems, supplied by BIOPAC System Inc. http://www.biopac.com/) at 8 sites (F3, F4, C3, C4, P3, P4, O1, and O2), placed in accordance with the International 10-20 System, referred to linked earlobes, and filtered online (band-pass 0.1-40 Hz). Central and occipital sites were included to verify the specificity of the hypothesized associations between the AC and the frontal and parietal EEG activity. The electrooculogram (EOG) was measured with electrodes located 2 cm above and below the right eye. Signals were amplified by the BIOPAC MP150 data acquisition system (gain = 20.000). The sampling rate was 500 Hz, and the electrode impedance was kept below 10 k. EEG recordings were first visually inspected to find the ocular and movement artifacts. Only 1 minute (30.000 data points) of continuous artifact-free EEG recording in each condition was taken (from second 30 to second 90, approximately); this was further processed with the EEGLab software (Swartz Center of Computational Neuroscience, University of California, San Diego). 20 Eye blinks were corrected along all the EEG channels by means of a correlational algorithm that took the EOG channel as the reference. The α (8-13 Hz), β (13-30 Hz), β1 (13-20 Hz), and β2 (20-30 Hz) power were obtained for each of the 8 brain locations. These frequency ranges were taken following Davidson et al. 21 An asymmetry index (ln PowerRight-ln PowerLeft) was then calculated for each brain area and condition.

FD was calculated using the Katz 22 algorithm; defined as log(n)/((log(n) + log(d/L)), where n is the total number of data points in the time series, L is the total length of the data section (ie, the sum of Euclidean distances between successive data points), and d is the diameter of the data (ie, the Euclidean distance between the first data point and the point that provides the farthest distance). Time units were set to 0.10 seconds to acquire FD values within the range of 1 < FD < 2. The FD values for each site and condition were calculated. Next, the average FD value for the EC and EO conditions for each site were obtained. Finally, a FD asymmetry index was calculated (FD right-FD left).

sec.title: Data Analysis
sec.p: Relationships between self-reported levels of attentional control and asymmetry indices were first analyzed through bivariate correlations (Pearson r) and second through the partial correlations controlling for trait anxiety. Statistical significance was adjusted, using the Bonferroni correction, to avoid the problem of multiple comparisons (inflation of type I error). Statistical analysis was performed using SPSS 15.0 (IBM Software, http://www.ibm.com/us/en/) for Windows.

sec.title: Descriptive Statistics and Correlations Between Self-Reported Variables
sec.p: As expected, the trait anxiety (M = 24.36, SD = 11.561) was significantly positively associated with sensitivity to punishment (M = 11.75, SD = 5.995; r = .614, P < .001), while AC (M = 4.034, SD = 1.189) was negatively associated with anxiety (r = −.571, P < .001). Table 1 shows the descriptive statistics for EEG asymmetry indices.

caption.p: Descriptive Statistics of Asymmetry Indices (n = 58) a

fn.p: Abbreviations: M, mean; SD, standard deviation.

a Asymmetry indices obtained by lnPowerRight-lnpowerLeft for frontal and parietal cortex in eyes open, eyes closed, and total conditions for α, 8 to 13 Hz, β, 13 to 30 Hz, β1, 13 to 20 Hz, β2, 20 to 30 Hz, and fractal dimension measured by Katz index.

caption.p: Bivariate Correlations Between the Frontal and the Parietal Electroencephalogram Asymmetries and Attentional Control (n = 58) a,b,c,d

fn.p: a Italics indicates partial correlations controlling the trait anxiety.
b Exact P values are shown in parentheses.
c Asymmetry index obtained by lnPowerRight-lnPowerLeft.

d At α band, high asymmetry values indicate greater power at right side (greater cortical activity at left side) and viceversa. At β1 and β2 bands, high asymmetry values indicate greater power at right side (greater cortical activity at right side) and vice versa. For Katz index, high asymmetry values indicate greater fractal dimension at right region and viceversa.
f P < .0125 (Bonferroni correction for multiple comparisons).

sec.title: Correlations Between EEG Asymmetry Indices and Attentional Control
sec.p: Low AC was associated with less left parietal α and β activity as well as with low left fractal dimension (see Table 2), but no significant associations were found between the self-reported AC and the frontal EEG asymmetry indices.
After controlling for trait anxiety, significant associations mentioned above were retained only for the β2 band.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: As expected, participants with low AC exhibit a diminished presence of α and β EEG oscillations in the left parietal cortex, even after controlling for trait anxiety in the case of fast β2 oscillations. However, frontal EEG activity was not associated with AC. Since studies reporting associations between emotion regulation mechanisms and frontal EEG asymmetries 23,24 focused on the study of a reactive component of temperament, we speculate that frontal EEG asymmetry may be involved in regulatory processes, while parietal asymmetry seems to be involved in the disposition to regulate emotions.

Low AC was associated with a diminished presence of α and β waves in the left parietal region (more α and β power in the right area). Traditionally, in the brain asymmetries literature, a predominance of α oscillations at 1 region (eg, F4) has been interpreted as a predominance of brain activity (cognitive work) at the contralateral region (F3). Similarly, the predominance of β activity at 1 site has been considered a sign of cognitive work or effort at that site. Our findings that both the α and the β oscillations are associated in the same way with individual differences in the AC seem to be at odds with these interpretations. However, Knyazev considers α as a watchfulness or preparedness rhythm with important inhibitory functions. In fact, the α rhythm would be more necessary in activity conditions than in relaxation. 16 Hence, the associations between AC and α activity should be stronger when participants have their eyes open (because attention to irrelevant stimuli should be inhibited even in such elementary conditions of visual processing), than when they have them closed, and this is what we found: the association between the AC and the α oscillations in the parietal regions was not significant in the eyes-closed conditions.

One study found that diminished left-sided parietal β asymmetry was related to difficulties in disengaging from attentional capture by angry faces. 15 Our results are in accordance with this finding, as low-AC participants also presented diminished parietal β activity in the left side. It should be noted, however, that Schutter et al 15 related asymmetries with motivational models of approach and withdrawal, and recorded a very fast, reactive attention response to probes (letters) after a 500-ms presentation of neutral or emotional faces. We, on the other hand, investigated 1 regulatory dimension of temperament (ie, AC); for example self-reported ability to refocus attention on a task after an interruption, or the ability to concentrate in the stressful conditions. More in line with this study, recent research supports the idea that attentional biases shown by anxious people could have their origin in attentional deficits at more basic levels (ie, less efficiency in attentional networks), as shown in the execution of nonemotional tasks. 4
–7

Recently, Kanai et al 25 reported an association between everyday life distractibility and the superior parietal cortex. This is interesting because they assessed distractibility with the Cognitive Failures Questionnaire 26 , whose items are very close to the items included in the AC scale used in this study. Although the authors did not record EEG activity (they measured the gray matter volume), they demonstrated that self-reported distractibility accurately predicted gray matter volume in a remarkable focal region of the left superior parietal cortex (which is near the P3 location). Based on the results of their repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) experiment as well as on the rTMS studies, 12
,13 they concluded that this region must play a causal role in reducing distractibility. The results of the present study are in accordance with this statement: fast oscillations (α and β) at rest in the left parietal region P3 are associated with individual differences in the ability to voluntarily manage attention. The studies by Mevorach and colleagues 12,13 suggest that the underlying mechanism is not paying attention to irrelevant and paying close attention to relevant stimuli, as this would be controlled by the right superior parietal lobe.

In this study, we also explored possible asymmetries in the complexity (FD) of the EEG as a supplement to the information obtained through standard analyses in the frequency domain. The left-sided enhanced EEG complexity corroborates the idea that α rhythm is not just an idling rhythm, but a type of oscillation with inhibitory functions that play an important role in the control of attention. If α oscillations were understood as a sign of “just waiting,” how could the enhanced β rhythm in the same location be interpreted? More α and more β oscillations give a more complex EEG pattern, and when this pattern is found in the left parietal region, it seems to be associated with good AC ability.

The γ band has not been included in this article, although several studies reported associations of it with attentional processes 27 as well as with several psychopathological disorders. 28 We decided not to analyze γ band, because the literature about EEG asymmetries and their relationship with emotional disorders and attentional processes traditionally has considered the study of α band almost exclusively. We extended the study to β bands to provide helpful information to interpret potential findings in α (following Knyazev’s 16 alternative interpretation of the α rhythm as a sign of preparedness or watchfulness), and the study of γ band was not included in the study for the sake of simplicity. We understand, nevertheless, the importance of studying the relationships between γ asymmetries and trait-like attentional control in future studies.

The main limitation of this study is that, because of its correlational nature, conclusions about the hypothetical causal relationships among the variables cannot be drawn. Future studies should also include the assessment of attentional network efficiency through laboratory tasks, in order to analyze whether the observed relationships, between the parietal EEG patterns and the self-reported AC ability, also appear to be associated with performance in nonemotionally laden attentional tasks. This would shed light on the potential disengagement difficulties that seem to underlie attentional biases to threat, and the proneness of anxious individuals to engage in self-focused emotion regulation strategies.

fn.p: Full-color figures are available online at http://eeg.sagepub.com

fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
